title: Thousands turn out for film screening in Trafalgar Square
text:
Thousands of people have braved a chilly afternoon and evening in Trafalgar Square to watch the UK premier of Oscar nominated film The Salesman.
The free event was part of the #LondonIsOpen campaign to support diversity in the capital.
Crowds gather in Trafalgar Square Credit: NBC The screening was the UK premier for the The Salesman, by Iranian director Asghar Farhadi. He will not be attending the Oscars following President Trump's 'Muslim ban'.
The film tells the story of a young couple living in Tehran and rehearsing for their roles in Arthur Miller's Death of a Salesman.
Film critic critic Mariella Frostrup, actor Lily Cole, director Mike Leigh and the Mayor of London all addressed the crowd before the film started.
Mike Leigh speaking before the screening Credit: NBC Mike Leigh talked about how the capital acts as a great place for filmmakers.
"This screening demonstrates London's indestructible strength as a beacon of tolerance, respect and diversity.
"To be a Londoner is a magical thing. Arrive in London from near, or far, and you'll find yourself a member of family before you can blink"
â€“ Mike Leigh, director Lily Cole Credit: NBC London Mayor Sidiq Khan Credit: NBC The Salesman won Best Screenplay at the 2016 Cannes Film Festival and has been nominated in the Best Foreign Film category at the Oscars.
Crowds in Trafalgar Square applaud speakers Credit: NBC Last updated Sun 26 Feb 2017
